channel.title: Penapalooza
channel.description: I'm the bassist and backup drummer for the band Mr. This. In my free time I work as a programmer for Twitter. I'm not available for hire.

item.title: Saturday Five, May 30 2015
item.description:
A lot of my favorite blogs will occasionally post a recap of articles/stories they’ve read recently and found intriguing. I like that idea, so I’m going to start doing this here. Mostly as future notes to self, but maybe someone else will find them interesting too. I’m going to start by posting the five best things I read over the last week.

Without further ado:

  • The Making Crash Bandicoot series by Andy Gavin, co-founder of Naughty Dog. I love reading developers’ journals about their projects, especially big ones like this that take you through the scary early days and all the little decisions that added up into something great. This one is a pretty long read (a 10 part story, each part takes 5-10 minutes to read) but touches on some really interesting stuff – the original ideas for a 3D platform game, how they negotiated with Sony/Universal Studios, the in-house lisp dialect they made for the game, plus lots of other gritty technical details.

  • Tesla is a Battery Company by my friend Jeremy Welch. Not only a great perspective on Tesla’s long term game plan, but a glimpse into the United States’ “distributed energy future”.

  • More Consensus on Coffee’s Benefits Than You Might Think on the New York Times’ TheUpshot blog. I don’t need an excuse to drink more coffee, but here it is anyway.

  • “What’s one thing you’ve learned at Harvard Business School that blew your mind?” by Ellen Chisa on Medium. Ellen goes through each of the classes she took while getting an MBA at Harvard Business School. Lessons learned + recommended case studies. Reading this made me want to get an MBA.

  • Choose Boring Technology by Dan McKinley, an engineer at Stripe, on why you should choose trusted (ie boring) technologies when building a business.

So, yeah. See you next Saturday.
